Preview: College Rugby Tens Tournament

10/03/2011

Freddy Harris takes us through the term's runners and riders for this year's College Rugby tens tournament (Thumbnail credit James key man Alex Muntus is held up in the recent College Final against Derwent)

Image by

By undefined undefined

After Derwent won the College Rugby final against a usually pre-eminent James team the black and whites will be keen to re-assert their dominance at collegiate level.They'll get the chance in the forthcoming tens tournament a usually thrilling afternoon of Rugby, won last year by a brilliant Alcuin side. Freddy Harris takes us through this term's runners and riders... James This year James have, predictably, been dominant in the 15's league, going unbeaten for a third year in a row. They swept aside nearest rivals Derwent 40-0, and even travelled to beat a Hull 3rds team in lieu of the UYRUFC 3rds. Their typically strong backs have been supplemented by an equally efficient pack, and they will take some beating. Why they'll win: As mentioned above, they've dominated in the 15s league, and don't look to have any obvious weaknesses. They'll also have added motivation after letting the cup slip through their fingers last year. Why they won't: They were in a similarly strong position last year and lost in the final to Alcuin, and also suffered scares against Derwent and Langwith. Complacency could be an issue, and the other teams will be looking to knock them off of their perch. Key man: Evergreen playmaker Alex Muntus is always a handful, but I think that the big tackling of Chris Smith will be essential for James to overcome the big teams. Watch out for: Ex-YUSU presidential candidate Aaron Rolph will be strutting his stuff for James for the first time this year after playing for the university 2nds. If they were a Rugby World-Cup team they'd be: New Zealand; dominant in many areas, but disappointing in the previous tournament. Can they deliver this year? Odds of victory: Evens Derwent Derwent's season has been mixed, with losses to James and the College Of Law overshadowing strong victories over all other teams. Still, they managed to finish 2nd in the table, and won a superb victory in the season finale. Why they'll win: Stronger than last year, where a semi-final loss against James went right down to the wire. They boast an excellent selection of loose forwards, and backs to rival James. In 10's their influence will only be magnified. Being an underdog will help, and they will want revenge for last year! Why they won't: Perhaps not as much depth as James, and a worryingly injury-prone squad could disrupt their rhythm. Key man Loose forwards have the ability to dominate in 10's, and I think Tolga Necar, in particular, has the ability to win rucks and turn over balls better than anyone else in college rugby. Watch out for: Dom Caunt; his runs are electric, and when he gets going he's a handful to stop. If they were a Rugby World-Cup team they'd be: England; once were all about the forwards, but now have a proper blend. They're also coming off of a good run of form, and full of confidence. Odd of victory: 2-1 Halifax Although not officially a team, they provided (nearly) all of the players in the demons during the 15's season. Got mixed results, and often struggled to field 15 players. However, its quality over quantity, and they got a win over Alcuin at the end of the season. All the sweeter considering they only had 14 players for the match. Why they'll win: Used to playing with depleted numbers, and showed glimpses of quality in their game against Derwent. The influx of university players will add some quality. They finished 3rd last tournament, and full rugby season will have only strengthened their credentials. Why they won't: Not as organised as the other teams, and getting university players isn't going to help that. May not have the same team bond as the other colleges. Key man: Captain Alex Simon is a complete centre, with pace, a good tackle, and the ability to pass the ball effectively. A useful player, but teams will look to cut off supply to him. Watch out for: Their uni players; will be interesting to see them come up against college players. How will they fare? If they were a Rugby World-Cup side they'd be: Australia; They have the players, and play excellent exciting rugby at times. However, their execution and organisation can let them down; still a huge danger from open play. Odds of victory: 5-1 Alcuin Much weaker than last year after losing the core to their squad, they'll find it hard to recreate their success of last year. Why they'll win: Have the largest pack in college, and if they use their size then they could provide colleges with something to worry about. Also have a few key players returning from injury in time for the tournament. Why they won't: Their pack's size makes it unwieldy and less mobile than the other colleges'. The loss of so many key players could make it difficult for them to link together properly. Key man: Paul Guest, who has played every 10s tournament at York to date, and probably will for the foreseeable future. His return from injury will bring valuable experience and creativity to the back line. Watch out for: A rolling maul in 10's, not seen since the dark days of early Derwent. If they were a Rugby World-Cup team they'd be: South Africa; Current holders, but seem to have lost their flair, and now rely on the ability to grind teams down with forwards. Odds of victory: 8-1 Goodricke Newly established as a team in its own right, Goodricke will only benefit from a full 15s season behind them. Being the largest college will have brought some quality freshers to the side, and haven't lost any key players since last year. Why they'll win: A large and enthusiastic squad, with a bit of experience to keep them grounded. Also might be able to attract some superstar university players. Man to man they are a match for most colleges. Why they won't: Still lack a bit of organisation, although that won't be as much of a hindrance in 10's. A single season may not be enough to bond them as tightly as Derwent or James. Key man: Goodricke have a good team spirit, and will have to keep it up if they want to get results. They'll need their captain Chris Smith (different one to above) to ensure morale doesn't drop! Watch out for: A master of the "dark arts" in the ruck (i.e. cheating) James Bowdler is excellent at slowing down the ball. Budding back rows should look to him for tips. If they were a Rugby World-Cup side they'd be: Argentina: relatively new to the scene, but quickly establishing themselves as a good college side. Worth an outside bet. Odds of victory: 10-1 Vanbrugh Much like Alcuin, Vanbrugh suffered this year, having to forfeit a number of their fixtures due to a lack of players. This time the culprit wasn't graduation but was a number of players choosing to ply their trade exclusively for UYRUFC. With a limit of a single University 2nds player for 10's, things could continue to be bleak for the men in green. Why they'll win: Much like Halifax, Vanbrugh have been playing most of the year with less than 15 men on the pitch. There's always the hope that the spatial awareness gained will aid them. They have a wide choice in which uni player they pick, which is a luxury not afforded to most colleges. Why they won't: Even less organised than Halifax, and being unable to put out a 15's side is foreboding. It also points to a lack of depth in the squad, something essential in the long, hard day of 10s. Key man: If they are to get anything then they will need Chris West to do a job at fly half and co-ordinate their team properly. Watch out for: Jordan Abbott or Jack Eastwood as the likely candidates for their university player slot. Their quality will be needed. If they were a Rugby World-Cup side they'd be: Scotland: Perhaps able to grind out a result, but mostly disappointing. Will have to prove me wrong. Odds of victory: 16-1 Langwith Have found it difficult to get players for their football teams, so a rugby team was always going to be a big ask. Gave James a scare last year, so perhaps can go all the way this year and earn a scalp. Why they'll win: Something of an unknown quantity, so teams won't know what to expect. Sam Asfahani is confident that they can get a full team together next year, and this is an opportunity to advertise themselves. Why they won't: Next to no preparation, and may even struggle to get 10 if they are unlucky. Unlikely that their squad could handle the stress of a whole days rugby Key man: Cameron Craig brings star quality to the side, with university credentials. A single player doesn't make a team, and he will hope to have some talent surrounding him. Watch out for: BNOC and Yorksport president Sam Asfahani. It's not every day you get to manhandle such a celebrity. If they were a Rugby World-Cup side they'd be: Tonga; not much known about them, but could pull a surprise or two out of the bag. Odds of victory: 25-1
